title: Top Ingredients for Men's Sexual Health and Erectile Dysfunction
author: Karolina Zaremba; CNP
description: Erectile dysfunction is an important condition to discuss as it impacts the quality of life and may be an indicator of other health conditions.
cleaned_text: is a condition estimated to affect 150 million individuals worldwide and up to 50% of men between the ages of 40 and 70. According to a report published in 1999, the prevalence of the condition is expected to increase to 322 million men by the year 2025. ( [12](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4004343/)) While there are various causes associated with the disease, psychological issues are implicated in approximately 20% of cases. ( [8](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2561113/)) Unfortunately, the condition can significantly affect quality of life, and many individuals are embarrassed to discuss the issue with their healthcare provider, resulting in the condition commonly being underdiagnosed. ( [8](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2561113/)) What is erectile dysfunction? Erectile dysfunction (ED) is a condition that is characterized by an altered erectile response, including being unable to achieve or maintain an erection during intercourse. ( [15](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5027992/)) Individuals may experience ED as either a short- or long-term issue. ( [11](https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/urologic-diseases/erectile-dysfunction)) During a healthy erectile response, the central nervous system or peripheral nervous system stimulates the dorsal nerve of the penis. This process involves the nervous, vascular, and endocrine systems. In cases of ED, a number of causes can impair this process, including: - Neurogenic causes, when a psychological or central nervous system issue inhibits vascular reactions - Arteriogenic causes, when the penis does not adequately fill with blood - Venogenic causes, when there is a dysfunction of the veno-occlusive system resulting in venous leakage and an incomplete erection ( [2](https://econtent.hogrefe.com/doi/pdf/10.1024/0301-1526/a000627)) Erectile dysfunction causes and risk factors A number of causes and risk factors for erectile dysfunction have been identified, including: - Being overweight or obese - Certain health conditions (e.g., atherosclerosis, type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, anxiety, depression, hypertension) ( [11](https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/urologic-diseases/erectile-dysfunction))( [12](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4004343/)) - Certain diuretics, antihistamines) ( [14](https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/004024.htm)) - Excessive alcohol consumption - Injury to the spinal cord, bladder, pelvis, or penis - Physical inactivity - Psychological issues relating to sex (e.g., low self-esteem, stress about sexual performance) - Smoking and recreational drug use ( [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2561113/))( [11](https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/urologic-diseases/erectile-dysfunction)) Signs, symptoms, and complications The signs and symptoms of erectile dysfunction include: - Complete inability to develop an erection - Erections that do not last long during intercourse - Inability to develop an erection when intercourse is desired ( [11](https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/urologic-diseases/erectile-dysfunction)) ED may be an indicator of other underlying or related health conditions, such as coronary artery disease or obstructive sleep apnea syndrome. Research suggests that individuals under 40 years old with ED experience a seven times greater incidence of cardiovascular events compared to healthy controls. ( [2](https://econtent.hogrefe.com/doi/pdf/10.1024/0301-1526/a000627)) Supplement ingredients for men's sexual health Medical treatment currently focuses on relieving erectile dysfunction symptoms, ( [1](https://www.auanet.org/guidelines/erectile-dysfunction-(ed)-guideline)) and includes pharmaceutical ( [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2561113/))( [16](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19260845/)) Integrative treatment of erectile dysfunction may involve reducing alcohol intake, quitting smoking, [managing weight](https://fullscript.com/blog/factors-that-influence-weight-gain), attending counseling, ( [11](https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/urologic-diseases/erectile-dysfunction)) and incorporating certain dietary supplements. The evidence-based botanical herbs used in the following protocol have been associated with improved sexual function in men with ED. Korean ginseng (Panax ginseng) Panax ginseng, commonly known as Korean or Asian ginseng, has a long history of general therapeutic use in Asian countries. ( [13](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6190493/)) Its primary active component, ginsenosides, have been shown exert antioxidant, immunostimulatory, hepatoprotective, [cardioprotective](https://fullscript.com/blog/heart-health-foods), and anti-fatigue effects. Ginsenosides may increase the synthesis of nitric oxide (NO), which plays a role in relaxing smooth muscle cells of the corpus cavernosum, a column that forms part of the penis and contains blood vessels that fill with blood during penile erection. ( [10](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3735289/)) Korean ginseng may exert its effects in ED as a result of its ability to improve psychomotor performance, such as processing and reaction time, as well as through inhibitory and stimulatory effects on the central nervous system. ( [4](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16855773/)) Tribulus (Tribulus terrestris) Tribulus, also referred to as puncture vine, is a shrub and botanical herb that grows commonly as a weed in various regions with warm climates. Tribulus contains various protogracillin, have influence sexual function and fertility. ( [3](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3931200/))( [5](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30253697/)) Protodioscin may benefit individuals with ED by increasing the conversion of testosterone, resulting in an increased production of red blood cells and an improvement in blood circulation and sex drive. ( [3](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3931200/)) Maca (Lepidium meyenii) [Maca](https://fullscript.com/blog/maca), a plant in the brassica (mustard) family, is native to Peru and grows at an altitude of approximately 4,000 to 4,500m in the Andes mountains. ( [6](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12472620/)) The maca root, which provides iodine, iron, magnesium, and amino acids, is the part of the herb traditionally used for enhancing fertility. ( [16](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19260845/)) Maca is generally considered an [adaptogen](https://fullscript.com/blog/adaptogens) and has been shown to increase energy and reduce symptoms of [depression](https://fullscript.com/blog/depression) and [anxiety](https://fullscript.com/blog/natural-remedies-for-anxiety). Maca may improve male sexual health by increasing sperm count, improving sexual desire, and improving the perception of sexual well-being in mild erectile dysfunction. ( [7](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3184420/)) The bottom line Erectile dysfunction is an important condition to discuss as it impacts quality of life and may be an indicator of other health conditions. The evidence-based ingredients in this protocol may help to improve sexual function and desire. A protocol using natural supplements can be used therapeutically on its own or as an adjunct to existing erectile dysfunction treatment plan. If you're a patient, we recommend speaking with your healthcare provider to find out whether these supplements are right for your wellness plan. If you're a practitioner, view our [men's sexual health protocol](https://fullscript.com/protocol/mens-health-sexual-health).
